This manual describes &app; version &appversion;
Introduction
The XFce panel is part of the XFce Desktop Environment and features program lauchers, popup menus, a desktop switcher and more. The actual command to run is &app;. Many aspects of the panel can be configured through graphical dialogs.
XFce is a collection of programs that together provide a full-featured desktop environment. It aims to be fast and lightweight, while still being visually appealing and easy to use. The following programs are currently part of XFce:
Window Manager (xfwm4)
Handles the placement of windows on the screen and provides decorative borders.
Panel (&app;)
The program described in this manual.
Desktop Manager (xfdesktop)
Sets a background color or image and provides a menu when you click on the desktop background.
File Manager (xffm)
Fast file manager.
Utilities
Several smaller programs and scripts, for instance a taskbar (xftaskbar4) and a run dialog (xfrun4).
For more information visit the XFce website.
Getting Started
The usual way to run the panel is at the end of your ~/.xinitrc file or ~/.xsession if you use a graphical login manager.
Here is an example of such a file, also using other components of the XFce Desktop Environment:
# window manager (go to background after initialization) xfwm4 --daemon
# taskbar xftaskbar4 &
# background, menu and other desktop settings xfdesktop &
# finally, run the panel # You can exit your session by choosing exit from the panel exec xfce4-panel
To find out how to obtain all these programs visit the XFce website.
Using the XFce Panel
When you start the panel you will see a bar apearing at the bottom of your screen, looking like this:
Default XFce panel
Shows XFce panel default configuration. Contains several launchers, a new mail monitor, a clock and a desktop switcher. Also shows an opened subpanel.
The figure shows the default panel configuration with one open subpanel and the mouse hovering over the setup button, making it show a tooltip.
The two strips on either side of the panel are move handles which you can use to drag the panel anywhere on the screen. Right clicking (or Shift-click) shows a popup menu — go on, try it ;-)
The area between the move handles contains panel items. There are several types of items, for instance program launchers, a clock and a desktop switcher.
Most items perform an action when clicked, like launching a program or switching to another virtual desktop. Right-clicking will open a popup menu, from which you can open a dialog to change item properties, remove an item or add a new item to the panel.
Panel items can have a subpanel associated with it, which can be opened by clicking on the button next to the item. Use the right mouse button to open a dialog to change the properties of the items on the subpanel.
Panel preferences can be changed from the XFce settings manager, which can be started either from the 'Setup' button on the panel (see ) or from the right-click menu on the move handles.
Customization
Panel Preferences
The properties dialog for the XFce panel can be opened from the XFce settings manager, which can be started from the panel using the setup button as shown in or from the right-click menu on the panel handles. The latter menu also provides direct access to the panel properties dialog.
Size, orientation, popup position and icon theme.
Panel layer and centering.
Panel Items
You can add panel items from the right-click menu on another item or the move handles. To remove panel items use the right-click menu or the 'Remove' button in the item properties dialog.
The properties dialog can be opened from the right-click menu on the item. Each type of panel item has its own configuration dialog. You can also change to another item type in this dialog, e.g. turn a launcher icon into a clock or vice versa.
Launcher, clock, mailcheck, switcher and systembuttons.
Subpanels
Use the 'Add laucher' item at the top of a subpanel to add an item to a subpanel or drag an executable to this item from a file manager. To remove items from a subpanel use the 'Remove' button in the item properties dialog.
The properties dialog for a subpanel item is opened immediately when clicking the right mouse button. The dialog itself is very similar to the dialog for Launcher type panel items.
